text: {"answer": "A", "reasoning": "Option A follows the standard ECHR judicial pattern where, having made a substantive finding under one article (here Article 9, referenced in paragraph 53), the Court declares related complaints admissible but exercises its discretion not to examine separately whether other provisions have been violated, as such examination would add no further value to the protection of rights. This 'no need to examine separately' doctrine is characteristic of the Court's reasoning when complaints are accessory to a main finding. The other options (B, C, D) concern admissibility determinations or lack of substantiation without reference to prior substantive findings, making them incompatible with the context implied by the reference to paragraph 53 and Article 9."}
